units.title: Integrals review
units.description: Review what integrals are and basic ways of calculating them.

contents.title: Introduction to integral calculus
contents.description: The basic idea of Integral calculus is finding the area under a curve. To find it exactly, we can divide the area into infinite rectangles of infinitely small width and sum their areas‚Äîcalculus is great for working with infinite things! This idea is actually quite rich, and it's also tightly related to Differential calculus, as you will see in the upcoming videos.

keyMoments.label: Introduction to the problem of finding the area under a curve
Approximating the area with rectangles
Improving the approximation by using smaller rectangles
Introducing the concept of integral calculus
Connecting integral calculus to the notion of a derivative

contents.title: Exploring accumulation of change
contents.description: Definite integrals are interpreted as the accumulation of quantities. Learn why this is so and how this can be used to analyze real-world contexts.

contents.title: Over- and under-estimation of Riemann sums
contents.description: Riemann sums are approximations of area, so usually they aren't equal to the exact area. Sometimes they are larger than the exact area (this is called overestimation) and sometimes they are smaller (this is called underestimation).

keyMoments.label: Introduction to Riemann sums
Choosing subdivisions
Left Riemann sum
Right Riemann sum

contents.title: Left & right Riemann sums

contents.title: Trapezoidal sums
contents.description: The area under a curve is commonly approximated using rectangles (e.g. left, right, and midpoint Riemann sums), but it can also be approximated by trapezoids. Trapezoidal sums actually give a better approximation, in general, than rectangular sums that use the same number of subdivisions.

Simplifying the expression
Evaluating the expression

contents.title: Definite integral as the limit of a Riemann sum
contents.description: Definite integrals represent the exact area under a given curve, and Riemann sums are used to approximate those areas. However, if we take Riemann sums with infinite rectangles of infinitely small width (using limits), we get the exact area, i.e. the definite integral!

contents.title: Indefinite integral of 1/x
contents.description: In differential ‚Äãcalculus¬†we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw, this is ln(x). However, if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

Deriving the derivative of the natural log of the absolute value of x
Conclusion: the antiderivative of 1/x is the natural log of the absolute value of x plus c

contents.description: Integration using trigonometric identities

contents.title: Integration by parts intro
contents.description: This video explains integration by parts, a technique for finding antiderivatives. It starts with the product rule for derivatives, then takes the antiderivative of both sides. By rearranging the equation, we get the formula for integration by parts. It helps simplify complex antiderivatives.

contents.title: Integration by parts: ‚à´x‚ãÖcos(x)dx
contents.description: This video shows how to find the antiderivative of x*cos(x) using integration by parts. It assigns f(x)=x and g'(x)=cos(x), making f'(x)=1 and g(x)=sin(x). The formula becomes x*sin(x) - ‚à´sin(x)dx, which simplifies to x*sin(x) + cos(x) + C.

contents.title: Integration by parts: ‚à´ln(x)dx
contents.description: This video shows how to find the antiderivative of the natural log of x using integration by parts. We rewrite the integral as ln(x) times 1dx, then choose f(x) = ln(x) and g'(x) = 1. The antiderivative is xln(x) - x + C.

contents.title: Integration by  parts: ‚à´x¬≤‚ãÖùëíÀ£dx
contents.description: Integration by parts helps find antiderivatives of products of functions. We assign f(x) and g'(x) to parts of the product. Then, we find f'(x) and g(x). The formula is ‚à´f(x)g'(x)dx = f(x)g(x) - ‚à´f'(x)g(x)dx. Sometimes, we use integration by parts twice!

contents.title: Integration by parts: ‚à´ùëíÀ£‚ãÖcos(x)dx
contents.description: In the video, we learn about integration by parts to find the antiderivative of e^x * cos(x). We assign f(x) = e^x and g'(x) = cos(x), then apply integration by parts twice. The result is the antiderivative e^x * sin(x) + e^x * cos(x) / 2 + C.

contents.title: Integration by parts
contents.description: Practice finding indefinite integrals using the method of integration by parts.

contents.title: Integration by parts: definite integrals
contents.description: When finding a definite integral using integration by parts, we should first find the antiderivative (as we do with indefinite integrals), but then we should also evaluate the antiderivative at the boundaries and subtract.

contents.title: Introduction to improper integrals
contents.description: Improper integrals are definite integrals where one or both of the ‚Äãboundaries¬†is at infinity, or where the integrand has a vertical asymptote in the interval of integration. As crazy as it may sound, we can actually calculate some improper integrals using some clever methods that involve limits.

contents.title: Differential equations introduction
contents.description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

contents.title: Writing a differential equation
contents.description: Differential equations describe relationships that involve quantities and their rates of change. See how we write the equation for such a relationship.

contents.title: Write differential equations
contents.description: Write differential equations based on the description of a relationship between two quantities.

contents.title: Verifying solutions to differential equations
contents.description: We can check whether a potential solution to a differential equation is indeed a solution. What we need to do is differentiate and substitute both the solution and the derivative into the equation.

contents.title: Verify solutions to differential equations
contents.description: Solve some basic problems about checking or finding particular and general solutions to differential equations.

contents.title: Slope fields introduction
contents.description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

contents.title: Worked example: equation from slope field
contents.description: Given a slope field and a few differential equations, we can determine which equation corresponds to the slope field by considering specific slopes.

contents.title: Worked example: slope field from equation
contents.description: Given a differential equation in x and y, we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x,y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we match an equation to its slope field by considering the various slopes in the diagram.

contents.title: Worked example: forming a slope field
contents.description: Given a differential equation in x and y, we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x,y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we determine the slopes of a few segments in the slope field of an equation.

contents.title: Slope fields & equations
contents.description: Work on the relationship between differential equations and the slope field that represents them.

contents.title: Approximating solution curves in slope fields
contents.description: Given the slope field of a differential equation, we can sketch various solutions to the equation.

contents.title: Worked example: range of solution curve from slope field
contents.description: Given the slope field of a differential equation, we can sketch various solutions to the equation. In this example, we analyze the range of a specific solution.

contents.title: Reasoning using slope fields
contents.description: Analyze slope fields that describe differential equations in order to find particular or general solutions to those equations.

contents.title: Euler's method
contents.description: Euler's method is a numerical tool for approximating values for solutions of differential equations. See how (and why) it works.

contents.title: Worked example: Euler's method
contents.description: Finding the initial condition based on the result of approximating with Euler's method.

contents.title: Euler's method
contents.description: Using the result of an Euler's method approximation to find a missing parameter.

contents.title: Separable differential equations

contents.title: Exponential models & differential equations (Part 1)
contents.description: Assuming a quantity grows proportionally to its size results in the general equation dy/dx=ky. Solving it with separation of variables results in the general exponential function y=Ce·µèÀ£.

contents.description: Population should grow proportionally to its size, but it can't keep growing forever! Learn more about this problem, posed by Malthus, and embark on a journey towards its mathematical solution.

contents.title: Logistic equations (Part 1)

contents.title: Logistic equations (Part 2)
contents.description: Finding the general solution of the general logistic equation¬†dN/dt=rN(1-N/K). The solution is kind of hairy, but it's worth bearing with us!

units.title: Parametric equations, polar coordinates, and vector-valued functions
units.description: We are used to working with functions whose output is a single variable, and whose graph is defined with Cartesian, i.e., (x,y) coordinates. But there can be other functions! For example, vector-valued functions can have two variables or more as outputs! Polar functions are graphed using polar coordinates, i.e., they take an angle as an input and output a radius! Learn about these functions and how we apply the concepts of the derivative and the integral on them.

contents.title: Parametric equations intro

contents.title: Partial sums: term value from partial sum
contents.description: The partial sum of a sequence gives us the sum of the first n terms in the sequence. If we know the formula for the partial sums of a sequence, we can find the value of any term in the sequence.

contents.title: Partial sums intro
contents.description: Solve some problems related to sequence, series, and their partial sums.

contents.title: Infinite series as limit of partial sums
contents.description: Infinite series are defined as the limit of the infinite sequence of partial sums. Since we already know how to work with limits of sequences, this definition is really useful.

contents.title: Partial sums & series
contents.description: Determine whether series converge or diverge based on their partial sums.

contents.title: Worked example: convergent geometric series
contents.description: Sal evaluates the infinite geometric series 8+8/3+8/9+... Because the common ratio's absolute value is less than 1, the series converges to a finite number.

contents.title: Worked example: divergent geometric series
contents.description: Sal evaluates the infinite geometric series -0.5+1.5-4.5+... Because the common ratio's absolute value is greater than 1, the series doesn't converge.

contents.title: Infinite geometric series
contents.description: Find the sum of an infinite geometric series, but only if it converges!

contents.title: Infinite geometric series word problem: bouncing ball
contents.description: Watch Sal determine the total vertical distance a bouncing ball moves using an infinite geometric series.

contents.title: Infinite geometric series word problem: repeating decimal
contents.description: See how we can write a repeating decimal as an infinite geometric series.

contents.title: Proof of infinite geometric series formula
Convergent & divergent geometric series (with manipulation)
contents.description: Sal looks at examples of three infinite geometric series and determines if each of them converges or diverges. To do that, he needs to manipulate the expressions to find the common ratio.

topics.title: Series: Quiz 1
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

contents.title: nth term divergence test
contents.description: If the terms of an infinite series don't approach zero, the series must diverge. Learn more about this test in this video.

contents.title: nth term test
contents.description: Practice using the nth term test to determine sequence divergence.

contents.title: Integral test
contents.description: The integral test helps us determine a series convergence by comparing it to an improper integral, which is something we already know how to find. Learn how it works in this video.

contents.title: Worked example: Integral test
contents.description: See how the integral test is put to use in determining whether a sequence converges or diverges.

contents.title: Integral test
contents.description: Use the integral test to determine whether a given series is convergent or divergent.

contents.title: Harmonic series and ùëù-series
contents.description: ùëù-series is a family of series where the terms are of the form 1/(n·µñ) for some value of ùëù. The Harmonic series is the special case where ùëù=1. These series are very interesting and useful.

contents.title: Worked example: p-series
contents.description: p-series are infinite sums Œ£(1/x·µñ) for some positive p. In this video you will see examples of identifying whether a p-series converges or diverges.

contents.title: p-series
contents.description: Determine whether a given p-series is convergent or divergent.

contents.title: Direct comparison test
contents.description: If every term in one series is less than the corresponding term in some convergent series, it must converge as well. This notion is at the basis of the direct convergence test. Learn more about it here.

contents.title: Worked example: direct comparison test
contents.description: Using the direct comparison test to determine that the infinite sum of 1/(2‚Åø+n) converges by comparing it to the infinite sum 1/2‚Åø.

contents.title: Direct comparison test
contents.description: Use the direct comparison test to determine whether series converge or diverge.

contents.title: Limit comparison test
contents.description: In some cases where the direct comparison test is inconclusive, we can use the limit comparison test. Learn more about it here.

contents.title: Worked example: limit comparison test
contents.description: To use the limit comparison test for a series S‚ÇÅ, we need to find another series S‚ÇÇ that is similar in structure (so the infinite limit of S‚ÇÅ/S‚ÇÇ is finite) and whose convergence is already determined. See a worked example of using the test in this video.

contents.title: Limit comparison test
contents.description: Use the limit comparison test to determine whether series converge or diverge.

contents.title: Proof: harmonic series diverges
contents.description: Showing that the harmonic series 1 + ¬Ω + ‚Öì + ¬º + ... actually diverges, using the direct comparison test. This proof is famous for its clever use of algebraic manipulation!

contents.title: Alternating series test
contents.description: When a series alternates (plus, minus, plus, minus,...) there's a fairly simple way to determine whether it converges or diverges: see if the terms of the series approach 0.

contents.title: Worked example: alternating series
contents.description: Example using the alternating series test to determine which values of a variable will make the series converge.

contents.title: Alternating series test
contents.description: Practice your understanding of the alternating series test and determine whether given series converge conditionally or absolutely.

contents.title: Ratio test
contents.description: The ratio test is a most useful test for series convergence. It caries over intuition from geometric series to more general series. Learn more about it here.

contents.title: Ratio test
contents.description: Practice using the ratio test in order to determine whether a series converges or diverges.

contents.title: Conditional & absolute convergence
contents.description: "Absolute convergence" means a series will converge even when you take the absolute value of each term, while "Conditional convergence" means the series converges but not absolutely.

contents.title: Determine absolute or conditional convergence
contents.description: Determine whether a given series converges absolutely, conditionally, or not at all.

topics.title: Series: Quiz 2
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

contents.title: Alternating series remainder
contents.description: By computing only the first few terms of an alternating series, we can get a pretty good estimate for the infinite sum. ¬†See why.

contents.title: Worked example: alternating series remainder
contents.description: Using the alternating series remainder to approximating the sum of an alternating series to a given error bound.

contents.title: Alternating series remainder
contents.description: Apply the alternating series remainder to approximate alternating series to a given error bound.

contents.title: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials intro (part 1)
contents.description: A Taylor series is a clever way to approximate any function as a polynomial with an infinite number of terms. Each term of the Taylor polynomial comes from the function's derivatives at a single point.

contents.title: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials intro (part 2)
contents.description: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. In this video we come up with the general formula for the nth term in a Taylor polynomial.

contents.title: Worked example: Maclaurin polynomial
contents.description: Finding the second degree Maclaurin polynomial of 1/‚àö(x+1).

contents.title: Worked example: coefficient in Maclaurin polynomial
contents.description: Finding the coefficient of the x¬≤ term in a Maclaurin polynomial, given the formula for the value of any derivative at x=0.

contents.title: Worked example: coefficient in Taylor polynomial
contents.description: Finding the coefficient of the term containing (x+2)‚Å¥ in the Taylor polynomial centered at x=-2 of x‚Å∂-x¬≥.

contents.title: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials
contents.description: Approximate functions using Taylor and Maclaurin polynomials.

contents.title: Visualizing Taylor polynomial approximations
contents.description: Approximating eÀ£¬†with a Taylor polynomial centered at x=3. In the video we find the first few terms of such a polynomial and graph it to see how close it gets to¬†eÀ£.

contents.title: Taylor polynomial remainder (part 1)
contents.description: The more terms we have in a Taylor polynomial approximation of a function, the closer we get to the function. But HOW close? Let's embark on a journey to find a bound for the error of a Taylor polynomial approximation.

contents.title: Taylor polynomial remainder (part 2)
contents.description: The more terms we have in a Taylor polynomial approximation of a function, the closer we get to the function. But HOW close? In this video, we prove the Lagrange error bound for Taylor polynomials.

contents.title: Worked example: estimating sin(0.4) using Lagrange error bound
contents.description: Lagrange error bound (also called Taylor remainder theorem) can help us determine the degree of Taylor/Maclaurin polynomial to use to approximate a function to a given error bound. See how it's done when approximating the sine function.

contents.title: Worked example: estimating eÀ£ using Lagrange error bound
contents.description: Lagrange error bound (also called Taylor remainder theorem) can help us determine the degree of Taylor/Maclaurin polynomial to use to approximate a function to a given error bound. See how it's done when approximating eÀ£ at x=1.45.

contents.title: Lagrange error bound
contents.description: Determine the least degree of a Taylor polynomial¬†necessary to approximate a function within a certain bound.

contents.title: Power series intro
contents.description: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form a‚Çô(x-a)‚Åø. Whether the series converges or diverges, and the value it converges to, depend on the chosen x-value, which makes power series a function.

contents.title: Worked example: interval of convergence
contents.description: The interval of converges of a power series is the interval of input values for which the series converges. To find it, we employ various techniques. See how it's done in this video.

contents.title: Interval of convergence
contents.description: Find all values of x for which a power series converges.

contents.title: Function as a geometric series
contents.description: Expressions of the form a/(1-r) represent the infinite sum of a geometric series whose initial term is a and constant ratio is r, which is written as Œ£a(r)‚Åø. Since geometric series are a class of power series, we obtained the power series representation of a/(1-r) very quickly.

contents.title: Geometric series as a function
contents.description: Power series of the form¬†Œ£k(x-a)‚Åø (where k is constant) are a geometric series with initial term k and common ratio (x-a). Since we have an expression for the sum of a geometric series, we can rewrite such power series as a finite expression.

contents.title: Power series of arctan(2x)
contents.description: We can represent arctan(2x) with a power series by representing its derivative as a power series and then integrating that series. You have to admit this is pretty neat.

contents.title: Power series of ln(1+x¬≥)
contents.description: We can represent ln(1+x¬≥) with a power series by representing its derivative as a power series and then integrating that series. You have to admit this is pretty neat.

contents.title: Function as a geometric series
contents.description: Represent functions with power series by recognizing them as the sum of an infinite geometric series.

contents.title: Geometric series interval of convergence
contents.description: When a power series is a geometric series, we can find its interval of convergence without using the ratio test!

topics.title: Maclaurin series of eÀ£, sin(x), and cos(x)

contents.title: Maclaurin series of cos(x)
contents.description: Approximating cos(x) with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

contents.title: Maclaurin series of sin(x)
contents.description: Approximating sin(x) with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

contents.title: Maclaurin series of eÀ£
contents.description: Approximating eÀ£ with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

contents.title: Worked example: power series from cos(x)
contents.description: Finding a power series to represent x¬≥cos(x¬≤) using the Maclaurin series of cos(x).

contents.title: Worked example: cosine function from power series
contents.description: Given a power series, we recognize it as the Maclaurin series of cos(x¬≥) and evaluate it at a given x-value.

contents.title: Worked example: recognizing function from Taylor series
contents.description: Sample AP Calculus question asking to recognize a function from its Taylor series.

contents.title: Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eÀ£
contents.description: Use the Maclaurin series of sin(x), cos(x), and eÀ£ to solve problems about various power series and functions.

contents.title: Visualizing Taylor series approximations
contents.description: The larger the degree of a Taylor polynomial, the better it approximates the function. See that in action with sin(x) and its Taylor polynomials.

contents.title: Euler's formula & Euler's identity
contents.description: Euler's formula is e‚Å±À£=cos(x)+i‚ãÖsin(x), and Euler's Identity is e^(iœÄ)+1=0. See how these are obtained from the Maclaurin series of cos(x), sin(x), and¬†eÀ£. This is one of the most amazing things in all of mathematics!

contents.title: Integrating power series
contents.description: Within its interval of convergence, the integral of a power series is the sum of integrals of individual terms: ‚à´Œ£f(x)dx=Œ£‚à´f(x)dx. See how this is used to find the integral of a power series.

contents.title: Differentiating power series
contents.description: Within its interval of convergence, the derivative of a power series is the sum of derivatives of individual terms: [Œ£f(x)]'=Œ£f'(x). See how this is used to find the derivative of a power series.

contents.title: Integrate & differentiate power series
contents.description: Practice integrating and differentiating power series, or analyzing the integrals/derivatives of power series.

contents.title: Finding function from power series by integrating
contents.description: When a power series S‚ÇÅ is an antiderivative of a geometric series S‚ÇÇ, we can find the function represented by S‚ÇÅ by integrating the expression for S‚ÇÇ.

contents.title: Integrals & derivatives of functions with known power series
contents.description: Represent a variety of functions with power series, using a wide range of algebraic tools.

contents.title: Interval of convergence for derivative and integral
contents.description: Integrating or differentiating a power series term-by-term can only work within the interval of convergence. The interval of convergence of the integral/derivative will be the same, except maybe for the endpoints. See an example here.

contents.title: Converting explicit series terms to summation notation
contents.description: Some sums are really long, but we can use sigma notation to write them in a shorthand way. See such an example here.

contents.title: Converting explicit series terms to summation notation (n ‚â• 2)
contents.description: Usually, when writing a series in sigma notation, we start summing at n=1 or n=0. Sometimes though, we would like to start at n=2 or larger values. See an example here.

topics.title: Series: Quiz 3
topics.description: Review the following recommended lessons to help you learn: {list of lessons covered by quiz}

contents.title: Telescoping series
contents.description: Telescoping series is a series where all terms cancel out except for the first and last one. This makes such series easy to analyze. In this video, we use partial fraction decomposition to find sum of telescoping series.

contents.title: Divergent telescoping series
contents.description: Telescoping series is a series where all terms cancel out except for the first and last one. This makes such series easy to analyze. In this video we take a close look at the series 1-1+1-1+1-...

contents.title: Formal definition for limit of a sequence
contents.description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value at infinity. This video is a more formal definition of what it means for a sequence to converge.

contents.title: Proving a sequence converges using the formal definition
contents.description: Applying the formal definition of the limit of a sequence to prove that a sequence converges.

contents.title: Finite geometric series formula
contents.description: A finite geometric series can be solved using the formula a(1-r‚Åø)/(1-r). Sal demonstrates how to derive a formula for the sum of the first 'n' terms of such a series, emphasizing the importance of understanding the number of terms being summed.

contents.title: Infinite geometric series formula intuition
contents.description: In the video, we learn about the sum of an infinite geometric series. The sum converges (has a finite value) when the common ratio (r) is between -1 and 1. The formula for the sum is S = a / (1 - r), where a is the first term.

contents.title: Proof of infinite geometric series as a limit
contents.description: The video provides a proof for the sum of an infinite geometric series using limits. When the absolute value of the common ratio (r) is between 0 and 1, the limit of the series converges to a finite sum. The formula for the sum is a / (1 - r), where a is the first term.

contents.title: Proof of p-series convergence criteria
contents.description: A p-series converges for p>1 and diverges for 0
